Dear Ms. Hardin:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
4/17/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samanatha Way, area manager at 517-243 -9743.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation
• (1) An agency social service worker shall
complete a written adoptive evaluation within 90
days of the family signing an adoption application
and prior to approving a family for adoption.
Two of three adoptive family evaluations reviewed did not complete the adoptive
evaluation within 90 days of the family signing an adoption application.
CPA Rule 400.12607 Agency recommendation
• (4) An agency shall provide the applicants for
adoption with a signed and dated copy of the
evaluation and recommendation upon its
completion.
Two of three adoption evaluations did not have documentation showing that the
applicants received a signed and dated copy of the recommendation upon
completion.

FOM Policy 722.08D Treatment plans - Agreement and Signatures.
Once completed and approved the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
Caseworker, Supervisor, second line supervisor, when
siblings in care are place apart, parents who are a
member of a participating household.
Youth ages 14 and older. Foster parents, relative
caregivers, and unrelated court – ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must
check yes or no for the following when signing the
treatment plan: I have participated in the Development of
the case service plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan.
Eight of eight foster care files reviewed were either missing signatures, signatures
were obtained after 30 days and yes or no were not checked on the PATP’s.
Repeat Violation Established
2023 Renewal, CAP approved 5/8/2023.

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with this individual CAP is as follows:The one
CAP submitted was in response to the 2023 renewal inspection completed on
3/20/2023 and the CAP was approved on 3/30/2023. The agency was cited for 2
violations, 1 of which was repeated this year. The repeated violation (722-08D –
PATP signatures) increased from 8 of 22 PATP’s in violation in 2023 to 12 of 27
PATP’s in violation in 2024 indicating additional corrective action planning is
needed. The agency will need to establish additional corrective action planning for
the repeated violation to ensure a reduction of this violation.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment (CAA) was discussed on site 4/12/2024 with
the Chief Administrator. The Chief Administrator (CA) reported the agency’s
barriers continued within the agency such as turnover of staff, worker and
supervisor oversight and the lack of effective new staff training. She identified
systemic barriers and factors that impact compliance outside of the agency control
are MiSACWIS errors, varying interpretation of rule and policy from county to
county, altering regulations, timeframes, and policies, even when they do not align
with the written policy and unrealistic timeframes and workload for current
positions.
The CA reported that MiSACWIS errors, though less than in previous years, do
play a factor in repeated non-compliance. The CA said the system unfortunately

is not fluid and adaptable to differing situations. Therefore, she feels agencies are
penalized when cases do not fit within the parameters of MiSACWIS. An example
is a parent in, in-patient treatment and the facility will not allow for monthly face to
face visitation per their policies. MiSACWIS does not have a way to capture this
without either penalizing the agency or penalizing the parent. The CA said the
agency receives a lower percentage for worker/parent contact until the parent is
released. Another MiSACWIS flaw and systemic barrier is when an agency takes
responsibility for a previously established case, any prior non compliances or
timeframes missed for that case are assume by the currently assigned agency.
The CA reported what is working and is a positive impact that occurred from the
last CAP activities were refresher of policies, procedures, and training
opportunities. In addition, a training series stemmed from their agency CAP this
past year, in which the foster care department hosted internal trainings on topics
that supervisors identified were barriers for front line staff. Trainings such as social
work contacts, relative home study, mileage, assessment writing, treatment plans,
parent engagement, and court and testimony training.
Financial Overview
The agency certified independent auditor’s report dated September 2022 and
2023, and the agency annual financial report was reviewed. There were no
financial concerns identified.
Staff Interviews
Four staff were interviewed onsite. Two staff interviewed were new and had
recently started working for the agency less than four months, the third staff has
work for the agency two years and the fourth staff interviewed has work for the
agency twenty years. The staff stated there is great teamwork and collaboration
at the agency and excellent guidance from administration when needed. Staff
were consistent in reporting their supervisors are very helpful, supportive and goes
beyond in assisting them when needed. The staff did not have any concerns
about the agency but indicated case aids to help transport for parenting time.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The office appears to have adequate space and equipment for the staff members
to complete their required responsibilities. Physical CHRI and case files are all
stored securely, preventing unauthorized access. No concerns were noted.

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
Safety Alert #1: The caregivers have a bedroom in the basement and there is no
means of egress.
Resolution: A discussion was held with the caregivers on 3/21/2024 via telephone
by the case worker. The caregiver stated this room has not been used as a
"bedroom" during their tenure as a licensed foster home. The caregiver admitted this
was previously used as a bedroom, two years prior to the family becoming licensed.
The room in the basement has remained a storage room since the caregiver’s
daughter moved out prior to licensure.
Per the caregivers 3130 assessment dated 12/16/2021 and subsequent annual and
renewal evaluations the "bedroom in the basement” has never been listed as a
bedroom. There is a photo that shows boxes and storage items and does not depict
a room being used as a bedroom.
Due to the rational provided, CCSEM did not initiate a special evaluation on the
caregivers, as there is no potential rule violation. A variance has not been requested
of the caregivers, as they do not wish to use the space as a bedroom.
Should the caregivers decide to utilize this room as a bedroom, CCSEM will ensure
that an egress window is installed prior to allowing anyone use it as a bedroom or
request a variance from DCWL. Photo of the bedroom is attached to the safety
alert.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
